message.content: To answer this question, we need basic knowledge about the comparative masses of celestial bodies. The moon is the least massive option among the given choices. The Earth is more massive than the moon, the sun is more massive than the Earth, and the solar system is comprised of multiple celestial bodies, including the sun, so it is more massive than the moon.

This question requires knowledge of the relative sizes and masses of celestial bodies. The moon is the least massive option because its mass is much smaller compared to the Earth, the sun, and the solar system as a whole. While the Earth is larger than the moon, it has a greater mass due to its higher density. The sun is significantly larger and more massive than both the Earth and the moon. The solar system consists of all the planets, moons, asteroids, and other celestial bodies orbiting around the sun, so it has a much greater combined mass compared to any individual body within it. Thus, the moon is the least massive option among the given choices.

To answer this question, we need to have a basic understanding of mass and the relative sizes of different celestial bodies. The moon is the least massive option because it has the smallest mass compared to the Earth, the sun, and the entire solar system. Option (A) is incorrect because the Earth is larger and has more mass than the moon. Option (C) is incorrect because the sun is much larger and has significantly more mass than the moon. Option (D) is incorrect because the solar system consists of multiple celestial bodies, including the sun, planets, and other objects, so it has a larger collective mass than just the moon.

This question requires knowledge about the relative masses of different celestial bodies. In this case, the moon is the least massive option. The Earth is more massive than the moon, the sun is more massive than the Earth, and the solar system encompasses both the sun and all the planets, making it the most massive option. Therefore, the moon is the least massive option of the four.

The Earth is more massive than the moon, and the sun is significantly more massive than both the Earth and the moon. The solar system consists of all the planets, moons, and other celestial objects orbiting the sun, so it is not an individual celestial body like the others.

This question requires knowledge about the relative masses of celestial bodies. The moon is the least massive option because it is much smaller than the Earth and the sun. The Earth has a mass of about 5.972 × 10^24 kilograms, the sun has a mass of about 1.989 × 10^30 kilograms, and the moon has a mass of about 7.342 × 10^22 kilograms. The option for the solar system is incorrect because it is not a celestial body, but rather a collection of celestial bodies.

The sun is much more massive than the Earth and moon, so option (C) is also incorrect. The solar system consists of the sun, planets, and other celestial bodies, so it encompasses a much larger mass than just the moon. Therefore, option (D) is also incorrect. This leaves us with option (B), the moon, as the least massive out of the given choices.
